DataElement.preferredName: Prostatectomy Specimen Biopsy Core Acute Inflammation Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The response of acute or chronic for inflammation in the biopsy core.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information pertaining to a bit of tissue taken from the prostate and used to determine a localized protective response resulting from injury or destruction of tissues.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (pros-ta-TEK-toe-mee) An operation to remove part or all of the prostate. Radical (or total) prostatectomy is the removal of the entire prostate and some of the tissue around it.:Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of part or all of the prostate.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: A localized protective response resulting from injury or destruction of tissues. Inflammation serves to destroy, dilute, or wall off both the injurious agent and the injured tissue. In the acute phase, inflammation is characterized by the signs of pain, heat, redness, swelling, and loss of function. Histologically, inflammation involves a complex series of events, including dilatation of arterioles, capillaries, and venules, with increased permeability and blood flow; exudation of fluids, including plasma proteins; and leukocyte migration into the site of inflammation. --2004

Concepts.definition: A finding of a localized protective response resulting from injury or destruction of tissues. Inflammation serves to destroy, dilute, or wall off both the injurious agent and the injured tissue. In the acute phase, inflammation is characterized by the signs of pain, heat, redness, swelling, and loss of function. Histologically, inflammation involves a complex series of events, including dilatation of arterioles, capillaries, and venules, with increased permeability and blood flow; exudation of fluids, including plasma proteins; and leukocyte migration into the site of inflammation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The response of acute or chronic for inflammation in the biopsy core.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having a severe and rapid onset of symptoms with short duration. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: Having a severe and rapid onset of symptoms with short duration.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disease or condition that persists or progresses over a long period of time.

Concepts.definition: Usually used to describe a condition that is persistent and long standing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.

Concepts.definition: Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.:The center of an object; indispensable:Having a severe and rapid onset of symptoms with short duration. In the acute phase, inflammation is characterized by the signs of pain, heat, redness, swelling, and loss of function. Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Having a severe and rapid onset of symptoms with short duration.

A finding of a localized protective response resulting from injury or destruction of tissues. Inflammation serves to destroy, dilute, or wall off both the injurious agent and the injured tissue. In the acute phase, inflammation is characterized by the signs of pain, heat, redness, swelling, and loss of function. Histologically, inflammation involves a complex series of events, including dilatation of arterioles, capillaries, and venules, with increased permeability and blood flow; exudation of fluids, including plasma proteins; and leukocyte migration into the site of inflammation.
